context: Act 3 Chapter 3.1 — Zero's car cathedral. Hundreds of vehicles. Impossible beauty. Every car has a story.

lines.text: A mountain road. No signs. No markings. The kind of road that exists because someone with enough money decided it should.
Echo drives. You sit in the passenger seat of a car you cannot identify — it moves like nothing you have ever ridden in, silent and fast and absolutely certain of itself.
The road ends at a door set into the mountainside. Not a gate — a door. Solid steel, fifty feet wide. It opens as the car approaches, and what lies beyond it stops your heart.

A cathedral. Not of stone and stained glass — of steel and carbon fiber and leather and chrome. A space carved into the mountain, vast as an airplane hangar, lit by diffused light that falls from above like grace.

Cars. Hundreds of them. Rows upon rows, arranged with the reverence of a museum and the precision of a military formation. Every era, every marque, every legendary machine that has ever turned a wheel.

A 1961 Ferrari 250 GT. A Porsche 917K in Gulf livery. A McLaren F1 in bare carbon. A Toyota 2000GT — one of only 351 ever made. A Mercedes 300SL with its gullwing doors frozen open, as if the car is perpetually arriving somewhere impossible.

And beside them — street legends. A Nissan Skyline R34 with a roll cage and competition numbers still visible under the paint. A Mazda RX-7 with a rotary engine that was illegal in three countries. Cars that were never meant to be precious — cars that became precious because of what they did.

lines.speaker: Echo
lines.text: Zero's collection. Every car here was acquired at the moment it became legendary. Not before. Not after. The exact moment when metal and engineering and human will combined to create something transcendent.
You walk among them. Your footsteps echo. The silence is sacred — the kind of silence that exists in libraries and churches and the spaces between heartbeats.
And then you hear a voice.

lines.speaker: Zero
lines.text: Every car here has a story. Most of them are tragedies.
Zero. A figure at the far end of the cathedral. You cannot see their face — the light comes from behind, turning them into a silhouette, a shape defined by the absence of detail.

lines.speaker: Zero
lines.text: The Ferrari was driven by a man who won Le Mans and lost his family to the racing he couldn't stop. The Skyline belonged to a girl who outran the police for two years before they caught up to her at the wrong time on the wrong road.

lines.speaker: Zero
lines.text: Speed has a price. It always has. The question is whether the bill arrives before or after the race.

choices.text: Why did you bring me here?
These cars are incredible. You've preserved history.
Cars belong on roads. Not in a cave.

lines.label: zero_explains
lines.speaker: Zero
lines.text: Because you are at a crossroads. The corporate world used you and discarded you. The underground loved you and couldn't protect you. You are between worlds, belonging to neither.

lines.speaker: Zero
lines.text: Because the underground you built was taken from you in a single night. And the question you haven't asked yet is: who gave the police the information they needed to take it?

lines.speaker: Zero
lines.text: I brought you here because I want you to see what exists above the underground and beyond the corporate. A third way. The real competition.

lines.label: zero_flattery
lines.speaker: Zero
lines.text: Preserved. An interesting word. One could also say 'collected.' Or 'captured.' The cars don't know the difference. They just know they are no longer moving.

lines.label: zero_amused
lines.speaker: Zero
lines.text: On that we agree. And soon, these cars will run again. On roads that make your underground circuits look like parking lots. I didn't bring you here to admire the collection. I brought you here to join it.

lines.label: zero_proposition
lines.speaker: Zero
lines.text: There is a circuit that exists outside all others. Not underground. Not professional. Elite. The best drivers in the world, competing for stakes that make championships look like children's games.

lines.speaker: Zero
lines.text: I created it because the world's racing infrastructure — both legal and illegal — is corrupt beyond repair. I created it because somewhere, there must exist a place where pure speed is the only currency.

lines.speaker: Zero
lines.text: Join my circle. Race among the elite. And in return, I offer you the one thing no sponsor, no team, and no underground can give you: the truth about how fast you really are.

choices.text: What's the price? Everything has a price.

lines.label: zero_price
lines.speaker: Zero
lines.text: The price is everything you were before you walked through that door. The professional. The underground king. The teammate. The protege. None of those identities serve you here.

lines.speaker: Zero
lines.text: In my circle, you are only what you drive. Nothing more. Nothing less.

lines.label: collection_end
lines.text: Zero turns and walks into the shadows between the cars. The silhouette dissolves. The cathedral hums with the memory of a thousand engines that once roared and now wait in silence.
You stand among legends made of metal and glass and wonder what it costs to become one of them.
